author: By Ben Sisario
title: Justin Bieber’s ‘Justice’ Debuts at No. 1, Ending Morgan Wallen’s Run
description: The pop superstar’s new album and the latest from Lana Del Rey bumped the country singer-songwriter to No. 3 after 10 weeks atop the Billboard 200.
content: After 10 weeks of domination by the country singer-songwriter Morgan Wallen, the Billboard album chart has a fresh champion: Justin Bieber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Sharpton and Crump warn that the ‘world is watching’ as witnesses begin to testify.
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton and Ben Crump, a lawyer for George Floyd’s family, told supporters on Monday, just as witnesses began to give testimony during the trial, that the world was focused on the case of the former police officer Derek Chauvin in the death of Mr. Floyd.
content: The Rev. Al Sharpton and Ben Crump, a lawyer for George Floyd’s family, told supporters on Monday, just as witnesses began to give testimony during the trial, that the world was focused on the case of the former police officer Derek Chauvin in the death of Mr. Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Sehgal
title: In ‘Philip Roth,’ a Life of the Literary Master as Aggrieved Playboy
description: Blake Bailey’s biography spends a lot of time on the minute details of its subject’s love life.
content: In 2013, Philip Roth was around 80, recently retired and finally at peace — or so he was fond of saying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: How to watch the Derek Chauvin trial.
description: The trial of Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd will be livestreamed from Minneapolis, and the public’s interest in the case may make this one of the highest-profile trials in recent memory.
content: The trial of Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd will be unusual for many reasons: It will be livestreamed from Minneapolis, attendance will be severely limited because of the coronavirus, and the public’s interest in the case may make this one of the highest-profile trials in recent memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Too Many People Are Locked Up for Small Thefts
description: An estimated 45,000 Americans are behind bars for thefts of less than $10,000. The punishment doesn’t fit the crime.
content: The United States has made some progress in reducing the shockingly large share of the population that lives behind bars, mostly by dialing back the War on Drugs. Building on this progress requires similar changes in the treatment of nonviolent property crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Matt Furber
title: Trial draws protests, TV coverage and a bonfire at George Floyd Square.
description: At the intersection in South Minneapolis where George Floyd died, people sat around a bonfire, discussing what would be unfolding a few miles away in the courtroom where Mr. Chauvin, the former police officer charged with murder in Mr. Floyd’s death, is on trial.
content: As the trial of Derek Chauvin began on Monday, local news channels were airing gavel-to-gavel coverage, while groups of protesters gathered on the streets demanding justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández and James Gorman
title: Virus Origins Remain Unclear in W.H.O.-China Inquiry
description: Far more work is needed to understand how the pandemic began, the report says, but it is not clear that Beijing will cooperate. “We may never find the true origins,” an expert said.
content: For 27 days, they searched for clues in Wuhan, visiting hospitals, live animal markets and government laboratories, conducting interviews and pressing Chinese officials for data, but an international team of experts departed the country still far from understanding the origins of the coronavirus pandemic that has killed nearly 2.8 million people worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Biden Pushes Mask Mandate as C.D.C. Director Warns of ‘Impending Doom’
description: The administration is stepping up the pace of vaccinations and expanding access to shots, but it remains in a race against a virus on the upswing.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden, facing a rise in coronavirus cases around the country, called on Monday for governors and mayors to reinstate mask mandates as the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention warned of “impending doom” from a potential fourth surge of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Amid Accusations of Rape and Misogyny, Australia’s Leader Demotes 2 Ministers
description: The attorney general and the defense minister, tied to separate scandals, will stay in the government, Prime Minister Scott Morrison said.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Seeking to address rising anger over accusations of rape and misogyny against members of his government, Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia reshuffled his cabinet on Monday, demoting two ministers tied to separate scandals, but keeping them in senior positions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Lara Trump Joins Fox News as a Paid Contributor
description: The daughter-in-law of former President Donald J. Trump appeared as a frequent guest on the cable channel during the 2020 campaign. Her hiring was the latest example of the revolving door between Fox and Mr. Trump’s circle.
content: Fox News just hired a Trump. But not Donald.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Larger Canvas for Your Easter Egg
description: Utopihen Farms offers six-packs duck eggs — large and golden yolked — nationwide.
content: Duck eggs, larger than hen eggs and containing bigger, deep golden yolks and a larger proportion of protein-rich whites, are sold at some farmers’ markets. Now Utopihen Farms has started selling the duck eggs nationally, raised on a group of small family farms with a home base in New Holland, Pa. Their duck (and chicken) eggs are from birds that forage in fields, and are given the title “pasture-raised.” The richness and size of the eggs are what make them so excellent scrambled, fried, poached, in omelets or however you like them. For baking you’ll need to adjust a recipe: The general rule is two duck eggs for three large chicken eggs. And for coloring and decorating for Easter, the eggs provide a larger canvas for your artwork, and they have thicker shells, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Nearly 200 Baby Tortoises Are Seized at Galápagos Airport
description: The tortoises were found on Sunday wrapped in plastic inside a red suitcase that was bound for mainland Ecuador. A police officer has been taken into custody, the authorities said.
content: Officials at an airport in the Galápagos Islands seized 185 baby tortoises on Sunday that were wrapped in plastic and packed in a suitcase that was bound for mainland Ecuador, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: O Dunedin: Canada Will Have to Wait to See the Blue Jays
description: Because of travel restrictions, one of baseball’s most promising teams will begin its season at a small park nearly 1,500 miles from home.
content: It has been 18 months since the Toronto Blue Jays played a game in Canada, and it is likely to be several more before the team can return to its home field at Rogers Centre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Baseball Puts the Regular Back in Regular Season
description: A return to a full 162-game schedule, with fans in the stands, has Major League Baseball poised to be a slice of normalcy in a world turned upside down.
content: It was over as soon as it started, more or less, the strangest little season in the history of baseball. Sixty games were all we got, not even 10 weeks — fewer games than a pro basketball or hockey schedule, fewer weeks than an N.F.L. season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: vehement
description: This word has appeared in 60 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Would You Want to Be a Teacher Someday?
description: Does the idea of becoming an educator appeal to you? Why or why not? Has being a student during the pandemic changed the amount of empathy you have for teachers? If so, what is different now?
content: When you think about your future career, do you ever consider teaching? If so, what grade level or subject area appeals to you the most? Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Sarah Kessler
title: How a Big Bad Bet Whacked the Markets
description: A margin call on Archegos Capital Management battered stocks and banking giants alike.
content: Credit Suisse and Nomura Holdings warned this morning that they faced huge losses from a multibillion-dollar fire sale of stocks held by just one investment firm, Archegos Capital Management. It’s the latest sign of the fragility of the global markets, and could spur more attention from regulators on the murky world of swaps and investor borrowing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Teenage Brains May Be Especially Vulnerable to Marijuana and Other Drugs
description: Teenagers are more likely to get hooked on marijuana, stimulants and other recreational drugs than college-aged or older adults.
content: Adolescents and teenagers who experiment with marijuana and prescription drugs are more likely to get hooked on them than young people who try these drugs for the first time when they are college-aged or older, according to a new analysis of federal data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Michael Corkery
title: Contentious Union Vote at Amazon Heads to a Count
description: The outcome of a vote at a warehouse in Alabama could have far-ranging implications for both the company and the labor movement.
content: SEATTLE — By the end of Monday, thousands of yellow envelopes mailed to a squat brick building in Birmingham, Ala., will hold the fate of one of the most closely watched union elections in recent history, one that could alter the shape of the labor movement and one of America’s largest employers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Czech Billionaire Is Among 5 Killed in Heli-Skiing Crash Near Alaska Glacier
description: Petr Kellner, the wealthiest person in the Czech Republic according to the Forbes list of billionaires, was part of the excursion, according to those who chartered the flight.
content: Five people, including the Czech Republic’s richest man, were killed on a heli-skiing excursion on Saturday when their chopper crashed near a glacier in Alaska, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: How Will We Win the Second Cold War?
description: Biden has a chance to turn China’s strengths into weaknesses.
content: In the First Cold War, the United States and our allies had a secret weapon against the Soviet Union and its satellites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: All Adults in New York Will Be Eligible for Vaccination Next Week
description: Those who are 30 and older will be eligible on Tuesday, and all other adults can be vaccinated starting April 6, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced Monday.
content: New York announced on Monday that it will make all adult residents eligible to receive a coronavirus vaccine by April 6, a symbolic shift in the state’s recovery from a deadly pandemic that has killed tens of thousands of residents and crippled the state’s economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: U.S. trade with Myanmar is suspended over killings by the military.
description: United States Trade Representative Katherine Tai said in a statement that the halt on a 2013 trade agreement with the country would remain in place until a democratically elected government is restored.
content: The Biden administration suspended a trade pact with Myanmar on Monday following one of the deadliest weekends in the country since the military ousted the civilian leadership and began a killing spree on civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Herrera
title: Tools to Protect Your Digital Privacy
description: A few simple tools go a long way.
content: This week I’ve invited Thorin Klosowski, an editor at Wirecutter, to give us some advice covering our tracks online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Inside America’s Most Interesting Magazine, and Media’s Oddest Workplace
description: The publication of the “Harper’s letter” attracted huge attention. Most people had stopped reading the magazine, which is stranger and better than you might expect.
content: Last August, when the pandemic seemed endless, John R. MacArthur, the publisher of Harper’s, asked his doctor about the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: A ‘major technical glitch’ brings an abrupt end to the first day in court.
description: The television feed of the Derek Chauvin trial is provided to news outlets by Court TV, which won approval from the judge to exclusively operate the cameras inside the courtroom.
content: The judge overseeing Derek Chauvin’s murder trial made history last year when he said he would allow television cameras to stream the trial live, a first in Minnesota history. But on Monday afternoon, the feed failed, bringing an abrupt end to the first day of one of the most anticipated criminal trials in recent memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brendan Porath
title: No Longer a ‘Tigress,’ Amari Avery Will Try to Make Augusta Roar
description: Avery, 17, and her dad once drew attention for their Tiger-and-Earl Woods aspirations. They hope to make a different sort of splash at the Augusta National Women’s Amateur.
content: It’s been eight years since Amari Avery made her first “splash” — her word — in golf. A 2013 Netflix documentary on elite grade school golfers introduced an 8-year-old Avery cruising her Riverside, Calif., street on her bike, pink handlebar streamers blowing in the wind, as Notorious B.I.G.’s “Going Back to Cali” blared in the background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: How a Surprise Candidate Has Shaken Up a Key New York City Election
description: The late entry of the City Council speaker, Corey Johnson, inserted tension, money and name recognition into the comptroller’s race. The winner will guide New York’s post-pandemic economic recovery.
content: The phone call came earlier this month, not long after Corey Johnson made his surprise late decision to join the New York City comptroller’s race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: What we know about the judge in the Derek Chauvin trial.
description: Judge Peter A. Cahill, a 14-year veteran of the bench in Hennepin County, ordered that the trial be televised, a first in Minnesota.
content: Judge Peter A. Cahill is a 14-year veteran of the bench in Hennepin County. He has previously worked as a public defender, private defense lawyer and prosecutor, rising to become chief deputy under Amy Klobuchar, now a U.S. senator, when she served as the county attorney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: The U.S. is concerned about China’s influence over a report on the pandemic’s origins.
description: The Biden administration has expressed concern over the Chinese government’s role in drafting a forthcoming World Health Organization report about the source of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The Biden administration has expressed concern over the Chinese government’s role in drafting a forthcoming World Health Organization report about the source of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: What We Got Wrong About Uber and Lyft
description: How can we believe that technology will help solve big problems if Uber’s great promise didn’t pan out?
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Sciolino
title: Hired by the Empress of Art at Tehran’s Hidden Museum
description: Donna Stein, in her score-settling memoir, reveals how she helped Farah Diba Pahlavi create a museum whose collection is valued at $3 billion today.
content: On the edge of a vast park in Tehran sits a Neo-Brutalist structure the color of sand. Inside is one of the finest collections of modern Western art in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: The Biden administration will investigate Trump-era attacks on science.
description: The White House Office of Science and Technology Policy intends to ask all agency leaders to identify political tampering in science-based policies and decisions over the past four years.
content: The Biden administration will investigate Trump-era political interference in science across the government, the first step in what White House officials described as a sweeping effort to rebuild a demoralized federal work force and prevent future abuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: As crews worked to free the ship, the internet demanded they ‘put it back.’
description: In the six days the Ever Given blocked the Suez Canal, it snarled global trade and cost billions of dollars. But it also brought a bit of light relief.
content: The saying goes that all good things must come to an end. But when it was announced that the ship that was stuck in the Suez Canal for days had been set partially afloat again — and could possibly be freed before the end of the day on Monday — social media users lamented the news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: An Alliance of Autocracies? China Wants to Lead a New World Order.
description: As President Biden predicts a struggle between democracies and their opponents, Beijing is eager to champion the other side.
content: President Biden wants to forge an “alliance of democracies.” China wants to make clear that it has alliances of its own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Remote Work Is Here to Stay. Manhattan May Never Be the Same.
description: New York City, long buoyed by the flow of commuters into its towering office buildings, faces a cataclysmic challenge, even when the pandemic ends.
content: Spotify’s headquarters in the United States fills 16 floors of 4 World Trade Center, a towering office building in Lower Manhattan that was the first to rise on the site of the 2001 terror attacks. Its offices will probably never be full again: Spotify has told employees they can work anywhere, even in another state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: They Set Aside Money for Their Commutes. Now They Can’t Get It Back.
description: Many people working from home or out of a job can’t access the hundreds of dollars deducted from their paychecks for transit expenses. “I’m unhappy because it’s a lot of money,” one woman said.
content: Any bit of savings helped when Eileen Damore was spending more than $400 a month to travel by train and subway from her Long Island home to her job at a printing company in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Cookbook to Plan for Summer
description: Vanessa Seder’s new book, “Eat Cool,” focuses on recipes that require minimal oven and stove use.
content: Is it rushing things to recommend a cookbook based largely on alluring dishes that are prepped and assembled, but mostly uncooked or barely so? It’s spring after all and the incentive to prepare salads instead of stews is compelling. Vanessa Seder, the author of “Eat Cool,” is a chef and writer based in Portland, Maine, who suggests recipes like a platter of judiciously spiced melon and cucumbers, scallop ceviche and an inviting array of tinned seafood. Other ideas include a green shakshuka, quick pasta with crab and chiles, a glass-noodle salad with lemongrass, fish sauce and seared ground pork, and a page of ideas for using a purchased rotisserie chicken. She has you use a stove and oven here and there, but not for a fruit pie because, as she explained in an email, baking a tart really heats up the kitchen. Instead, among her desserts is an intriguingly refreshing lemon semifreddo made with salted preserved lemons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Suez Canal Blocked After Giant Container Ship Gets Stuck’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how a lone ship has disrupted global trade already upended by the pandemic, capturing the world’s attention — and the imagination of the internet.
content: Featured Article: “Suez Canal Blocked After Giant Container Ship Gets Stuck” by Vivian Yee and Peter S. Goodman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Creamiest Asparagus Pasta!
description: Add a bit of seaweed to your weeknight pasta, as Eric Kim recommends, for subtle umami.
content: Good morning. Eric Kim has a lovely story in The Times this week about using seaweed to add subtle umami to dishes, as in this creamy asparagus pasta recipe (above) that tastes a little bit like shrimp Alfredo even though it contains no seafood. (You could always add shrimp, though. That’d be excellent.) The shredded seaweed snack sprinkled on top is what does it, along with cooking the pasta in a quick version of the Korean stock known as dasima yuksu. Won’t you give that recipe a try this week?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Police Seek Motive in Shooting Spree Near Baltimore
description: A man shot and killed his parents before killing two people at a convenience store in Essex, Md., on Sunday, the authorities said. The gunman later fatally shot himself.
content: The quiet of a Sunday morning in a community near Baltimore was shattered as a gunman killed his parents, two people at a convenience store and then himself in a shooting spree, a motive for which was not immediately clear, the police said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A chunk of world trade is stuck waiting for the Suez Canal to clear.
description: A journey from the Suez Canal in Egypt to Rotterdam, in the Netherlands — Europe’s largest port — typically takes about 11 days. Venturing south around Africa’s Cape of Good Hope adds at least 26 more days, according to Refinitiv, the financial data company.
content: A journey from the Suez Canal in Egypt to Rotterdam, in the Netherlands — Europe’s largest port — typically takes about 11 days. Venturing south around Africa’s Cape of Good Hope adds at least 26 more days, according to Refinitiv, the financial data company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Ship Is Freed After a Costly Lesson in the Vulnerabilities of Sea Trade
description: A single stuck ship stymied global trade for nearly a week. That raises fundamental questions about risks in the supply chain industry.
content: SUEZ, Egypt — For six days, billions of dollars’ worth of international commerce sat paralyzed at either end of the Suez Canal, stalled thanks to a single giant container ship apparently knocked sideways by a powerful southerly wind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Rhodes
title: A Biologist, an Outlandish Stork and the Army of Women Trying to Save It
description: In the Indian state of Assam, a group of women known as the Hargila Army is spearheading a conservation effort to rescue the endangered greater adjutant stork.
content: Life can change in an instant, as I experienced when I first laid my eyes on a tall and bizarrely striking bird known as the greater adjutant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Alvin Sykes, 64, Self-Taught Legal Defender of Civil Rights, Dies
description: After dropping out of high school, he studied law at the public library, then used his knowledge to reopen cold cases, including Emmett Till’s murder.
content: Alvin Sykes, who left high school in eighth grade, completed his education by reading legal textbooks at the public library and later used his vast knowledge of the law to pry open long-dormant murder cases from the civil rights era — including the 1955 lynching of Emmett Till — died on March 19 at a hospice facility in Shawnee, Kan. He was 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Paul Laubin, 88, Dies; Master of Making Oboes the Old-Fashioned Way
description: He learned the craft from his father and continued to make his instruments by hand. Laubin oboes are cherished for their dark and rich tone.
content: Paul Laubin, a revered oboe maker who was one of the few remaining woodwind artisans to build their instruments by hand — he made so few a year that customers might have had to wait a decade to play one — died on March 1 at his workshop in Peekskill, N.Y. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Judith Levitt
title: Chauvin Trial, Infrastructure, Vaccines: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 29, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Monday, March 29, 2021.
content: Because of an editing error, some of the photographs with a list on Sunday of the first 20 prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, were misplaced. In the third column of that article, each prisoner photograph should have been placed with the name immediately above. Ridah bin Saleh al Yazidi, listed at the bottom of the column, was not shown in a photograph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: What we learned from the opening statements.
description: Before prosecutors called their first witness, lawyers for both sides made opening statements to jurors in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with murder in George Floyd’s death.
content: Before prosecutors called their first witness, lawyers for both sides made opening statements to jurors in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with murder in George Floyd’s death. Here’s what happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: A 911 dispatcher said officers pinned down George Floyd for so long she thought the camera feed ‘had frozen.’
description: “My instincts were telling me that something’s wrong,” Jena Scurry testified in court on Monday.
content: A 911 dispatcher who watched the police pin George Floyd to the ground on a surveillance camera said in court on Monday that the restraint went on for so long that she asked someone if her “screens had frozen.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Meet the New U.C.L.A.: Plucky Underdog
description: After barely making the field of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, the Bruins are enjoying a revival under Coach Mick Cronin. Now they’re one win from the Final Four.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — When Hep Cronin, a baseball scout for the Atlanta Braves, would pack up the car for a trip to hunt for prospects, he would sometimes bring his two young boys, Dan and Mick. In the stands, they would ask their father which player he was watching, but he wouldn’t tell them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: ‘Is This Patriot Enough?’: Asian-American Veteran Reveals Scars as He Calls Out Bias
description: “People question my patriotism, that I don’t look American enough,” Lee Wong, an elected official in an Ohio township, said at a recent public meeting.
content: As town meetings go, the discussion was fairly routine, meandering from what Memorial Day celebrations might look like in the second year of the coronavirus pandemic, to a federal grant application for bulletproof vests for police officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Very Short Saga of the Guess Bag That Looked Like a Telfar Bag
description: Copycatting has social media consequences. After the BeyHive and the Rihanna Navy — the Telfar tribe?
content: For decades product plagiarism has been seen as the price of success in the fashion world: Make a hit bag or a viral dress and someone (sometimes many someones) will unabashedly rip it off, often almost overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Joe Biden Did Not Appear to Be a Master of Disguise
description: Whether you like him or hate him, the president isn’t quite who we thought he was.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, last fall we had a brief talk about filibusters and you said you didn’t like the idea of getting rid of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vindu Goel and Jill Cowan
title: Water Shortages and Fires Loom After a Dry Winter
description: Monday: An update on California’s water situation. Also: A stair-walking love story.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: New York Must Offer Vaccine to All Prisoners Immediately, Judge Rules
description: A judge in the Bronx ruled that people incarcerated in the state’s prisons and jails had been arbitrarily excluded from the coronavirus vaccine rollout.
content: New York must immediately begin to offer Covid vaccines to all incarcerated people in the state’s prisons and jails, a judge ruled on Monday, making the state one of few in the nation to provide doses to such a broad population behind bars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Killing of Salvadoran Refugee by Police in Mexico Incites Furor
description: Videos echoing the death of George Floyd showed a police officer kneeling on the back of the woman, who died of a broken spine, just days before an international forum on gender equality began in Mexico.
content: MEXICO CITY — The death at the hands of police of a woman who was a refugee from El Salvador has drawn international condemnation and potential embarrassment for Mexico, which on Monday began hosting a United Nations summit focused on gender equality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Ghislaine Maxwell Charged With Sex Trafficking of 14-Year-Old Girl
description: A new indictment accuses Ms. Maxwell of paying a victim of her longtime associate Jeffrey Epstein.
content: Ghislaine Maxwell, the longtime associate of Jeffrey Epstein, was charged on Monday for the first time with sex trafficking of a minor, as federal prosecutors accused her of grooming a 14-year-old girl to engage in sexual acts with Mr. Epstein and later paying her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: The Crossword Stumper
description: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
content: A TRY in rugby is a play that scores five points, and is similar to a touchdown in American football. One difference, however, is that the ball must be simultaneously touching the ground and an attacking player. After scoring a TRY, the attacking team attempts a conversion, which is analogous to the extra point in football.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Paul Mozur
title: How China’s Outrage Machine Kicked Up a Storm Over H&M
description: The Communist Party’s youth wing and official news outlets used grabby memes and hashtags to start a tsunami of nationalist fury over Xinjiang cotton.
content: When the Swedish fast-fashion giant H&M said in September that it was ending its relationship with a Chinese supplier accused of using forced labor, a few Chinese social media accounts dedicated to the textile industry took note. But by and large, the moment passed without fanfare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas A. Ashford
title: Not on Facebook? You’re Still Likely Being Fed Misinformation.
description: Broadcast television and talk radio are just as problematic as social media.
content: The plague of misinformation — false rumors about the legitimacy of the 2020 presidential election, the ineffectiveness of face masks and the safety of 5G, to name a few examples — is usually blamed on social media. But false and damaging information isn’t just available online. It’s also abundant in broadcast media, and as politicians debate whether or how to regulate technology companies, they should also consider creating systems to address the dangers implicit in allowing and enabling the spread of misinformation, wherever it’s published.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Weighing the Use of Growth Hormones for Children
description: New research has linked growth hormone treatment to serious adverse health effects years later.
content: An 8-year-old boy I know is small for his age, shorter and slighter than his friends, even smaller than his 5-year-old sister. Concerned about the increasing use and possible risks of growth hormone, I asked his mother if she’d considered treating him with it. She replied, “Not really. He’s built like his father, who was short and slight as a boy and didn’t shoot up until college.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Marc Santora and Rick Gladstone
title: ‘We pulled it off!’ After days of arduous labor, a ship is free, and salvagers are triumphant.
description: The operation that wrested the ship from an embankment where it had beached six days ago was one of the most intense in maritime history. Some Suez Canal traffic resumed within hours.
content: The mammoth cargo ship blocking the Suez Canal was wrenched from the shoreline and finally set free on Monday, raising hopes that one of the world’s most vital maritime routes would quickly rebound and limit the fallout of a disruption that had paralyzed billions of dollars in global trade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: U.S. Men Fail to Qualify for Olympic Soccer Tournament
description: Honduras dashes the Americans’ hopes of a trip to Tokyo, the latest in a string of qualifying failures for U.S. Soccer.
content: The United States failed in its latest bid to qualify for the Olympic men’s soccer tournament on Sunday, falling to Honduras, 2-1, in a regional qualifying tournament in Mexico. A goalkeeping blunder proved to be the difference this time, but the feeling — and the frustration — was all too familiar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: HarperCollins to Buy Houghton Mifflin’s Trade Publishing Unit
description: The $349 million deal will help the publisher expand its back catalog at a moment of growing consolidation in the book business.
content: HarperCollins, one of the five largest publishing companies in the United States, said on Monday that it had agreed to buy Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Books and Media, the trade publishing division of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, for $349 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Spencer
title: How Do Women Feel About Women’s History Month? Conflicted.
description: The pandemic, racial reckonings, economic hardship and a next-to-impossible year have made this March particularly fraught.
content: — Patrisse Cullors, a founder of the Black Lives Matter movement, on Women’s History Month
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Jack Bradley, Louis Armstrong Photographer and Devotee, Dies at 87
description: His trove of pictures formed the foundation of a vast personal collection that is now part of the Louis Armstrong House Museum in Queens.
content: Jack Bradley, an ecstatic fan of Louis Armstrong’s who became his personal photographer, creating an indelible and intimate record of the jazz giant’s last dozen years, died on March 21 in Brewster, Mass., on Cape Cod. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Michael Corkery
title: Counting starts Tuesday in the vote on whether Amazon workers in Alabama will unionize.
description: By the end of Monday, thousands of yellow envelopes mailed to a squat brick building in Birmingham, Ala., will hold the fate of one of the most closely watched union elections in recent history, one that could alter the shape of the labor movement.
content: By the end of Monday, thousands of yellow envelopes mailed to a squat brick building in Birmingham, Ala., will hold the fate of one of the most closely watched union elections in recent history, one that could alter the shape of the labor movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The Ever Given is partially freed.
content: In what appeared to be the bloodiest day of protests since the Feb. 1 military coup, at least 90 people were gunned down by Myanmar security forces on Saturday, according to a rights group based in Myanmar and Thailand. Myanmar Now, a respected news site, reported that 114 people had been killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Estrin
title: Behind Closed Doors, ‘the Difficulty and the Beauty’ of Pandemic Hospice Work
description: “I did not really understand when people would ask, ‘Why me and why my family?’” a hospice chaplain said. “Now I was asking the same questions.”
content: Hanane Saoui is used to death. Sudden deaths and slow deaths. Painful deaths and peaceful deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Looks for Narrow Path in Investors’ Suit Against Goldman Sachs
description: Both sides agreed that generic statements about firms’ integrity and honesty can sometimes be the basis for securities fraud class-action suits.
content: WASHINGTON — A frustrated Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday in a securities fraud class-action case against Goldman Sachs, with several justices indicating puzzlement about what they were meant to do in light of both parties seeming to agree about the governing legal standard. Two justices, using the same metaphor, said they saw little daylight between the two sides.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The bidding for Tribune Publishing got a surprise twist.
description: A Swiss billionaire who has donated hundreds of millions to environmental causes is a surprise new player in the bidding for Tribune Publishing, the major newspaper chain that until recently seemed destined to end up in the hands of a New York hedge fund.
content: A Swiss billionaire who has donated hundreds of millions to environmental causes is a surprise new player in the bidding for Tribune Publishing, the major newspaper chain that until recently seemed destined to end up in the hands of a New York hedge fund.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: The Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines are very effective in real-world conditions at preventing infections, the C.D.C. reported.
description: Consistent with clinical trial data, a two-dose regimen prevented 90 percent of infections by two weeks after the second shot. One dose prevented 80 percent of infections by two weeks after vaccination.
content: The coronavirus vaccines made by Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech are proving highly effective at preventing symptomatic and asymptomatic infections under real-world conditions, federal health researchers reported on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Lacey
title: A veteran of the O.J. Simpson legal drama has one eye on the set this time.
description: There are numerous similarities between the Simpson and Chauvin cases, including defendants who have become household names and media outlets broadcasting the cases live into homes across America.
content: There are some echoes between O.J. Simpson’s celebrated murder trial, which seemed to bring America to a standstill in 1995, and the widely covered proceedings that are underway on Monday at a courthouse in Minneapolis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: From a Brooklyn Railroad Flat to a Three-Bedroom With Doors
description: The pandemic made it clear that this mother and her two growing sons needed a place with more privacy.
content: For many years, Jen Brenneman’s two-bedroom railroad apartment in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, was just perfect. She moved into the space with her two young sons in 2015, after separating from their father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: More states are opening up vaccine eligibility to include all adults.
content: With the vaccine supply set to increase substantially, more states are opening up vaccine eligibility to  all adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: A Tawdry Tale of Local Graft Becomes a China #MeToo Moment
description: A young woman from a modest background gets a long prison term. The powerful officials who paid her draw lighter punishment. The Chinese public has questions.
content: The woman from a poor village was only 19 years old when she started a sexual relationship with a local police chief. Soon, she had trysts with other local leaders, including police and hospital officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
title: Biden Administration Announces a Major Offshore Wind Plan
description: The White House said the program could create tens of thousands of new jobs while moving the country toward clean energy
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Monday announced a plan to vastly expand the use of offshore wind power along the East Coast, aiming to tap a potentially huge new source of renewable energy that has so far struggled to gain acceptance in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Looking for Crickets, and Coming Up Crickets
description: The choreographer Madeline Hollander’s “Flatwing,” at the Whitney, considers a genetic mutation that silences some male crickets.
content: Madeline Hollander is an artist interested in quotidian movement, habits of motion, adaptations to change. So it’s fitting that her art caused me to return to a once quotidian activity that I had so far avoided during the pandemic. I visited a museum — the Whitney Museum of American Art, in New York, which is presenting Hollander’s first solo museum exhibition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman and Elizabeth Paton
title: What Is Going On With China, Cotton and All of These Clothing Brands?
description: A user’s guide to the latest cross-border social media fashion crisis.
content: Last week, calls for the cancellation of H&M and other Western brands went out across Chinese social media as human rights campaigns collided with cotton sourcing and political gamesmanship. Here’s what you need to know about what’s going on and how it may affect everything from your T-shirts to your trench coats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: George Floyd’s family, the news media and protesters gather outside the courthouse.
description: A scrum of reporters gathered on the lawn just south of the courthouse, where members of Mr. Floyd’s family and their lawyers held a news conference ahead of opening statements.
content: A helicopter whirred overhead on a sunny, yet chilly and windy morning on Monday in downtown Minneapolis, where the streets were largely empty and calm ahead of the big trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Navalny vs. Putin
description: Our Moscow bureau chief, Anton Troianovski, talks to us about Aleksei Navalny’s political machine in Russia.
content: Aleksei Navalny, the fiercest political opponent of Vladimir Putin, is in prison. He returned to Russia in January after recovering from a near-deadly poisoning in Siberia. After the police arrested him on charges that were widely seen as politically motivated, a wave of pro-Navalny protests swept the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
title: The Biden administration makes a swath of ocean between New York and New Jersey an offshore wind zone.
description: The White House said its offshore wind plan would avoid 78 million metric tons of carbon dioxide emissions and create tens of thousands of jobs.
content: The Biden administration announced a plan on Monday to vastly expand the use of offshore wind power along the East Coast, aiming to tap a potentially huge source of renewable energy that has so far struggled to gain a foothold in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Money is pouring into start-ups that are eager to upend Wall Street.
description: Thousands of financial technology start-ups are riding an investor frenzy driven by a growing realization that the industry is ripe for a tech makeover, writes Erin Griffith of The New York Times.
content: Thousands of financial technology start-ups are riding an investor frenzy driven by a growing realization that the industry is ripe for a tech makeover, writes Erin Griffith of The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Rich Get Richer With Nets’ Signing of LaMarcus Aldridge
description: Aldridge, a seven-time All-Star center, won’t be expected to play a leading role but will provide more depth to a team that has been excelling despite Kevin Durant’s injury.
content: On Sunday, Nets guard Bruce Brown learned from a reporter on a post-practice video conference call that his team had added LaMarcus Aldridge, the seven-time All-Star center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden’s Lesson From Past Green Stimulus Failures: Go Even Bigger
description: As vice president, Joe Biden oversaw a “green jobs” stimulus package that produced notable failures. This time, with more money and more demand for clean technology, will be different, Democrats say.
content: WASHINGTON — In September 2009, then-Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. traveled to a defunct General Motors plant near his hometown, Wilmington, Del., to announce a $528.7 million government loan for Fisker Automotive to make hybrid and electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: How Arizona Won the Weed Legalization Race
description: Four states voted to legalize recreational cannabis in November. Only one is selling it so far.
content: PHOENIX — When Arizonans voted to legalize recreational cannabis in November, it seemed plausible that sales would begin sometime in the spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Derek Chauvin on trial.
content: Derek Chauvin, a former police officer, faces charges of manslaughter, second-degree murder and third-degree murder in the death of George Floyd. Mr. Chauvin held his knee on Mr. Floyd’s neck on a Minneapolis street corner in May before he died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane
title: Democrats Look to Smooth the Way for Biden’s Infrastructure Plan
description: House Democrats face hurdles to pushing through the president’s big spending plans, including Republican opposition and resistance from their own ranks.
content: WASHINGTON — Senior Democrats on Monday proposed a tax increase that could partly finance President Biden’s plans to pour trillions of dollars into infrastructure and other new government programs, as party leaders weighed an aggressive strategy to force his spending proposals through Congress over unified Republican opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: He’s the Ideal College Athlete. So Why Did He Quit?
description: Hunter Woodhall made history in track and field, but N.C.A.A. restrictions on athletes’ earnings drove him out of college sports.
content: There has never been another college athlete like Hunter Woodhall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Sarah Onyango Obama, Ex-President’s Stepgrandmother, Dies at 99
description: Known widely among Kenyans as Mama Sarah, Ms. Obama was seen as the matriarch of Barack Obama’s extended family in Africa.
content: Sarah Onyango Obama, the stepgrandmother of former President Barack Obama who grew up without formal education in rural Kenya and devoted many of her later years to philanthropic efforts to help young Kenyans find places in school, died on Monday in Kisumu, a city in the western part of the country. She was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: How Manhattan Office Life Is Changing
description: Even after the pandemic ends, remote work is likely to endure, and companies are rethinking their spaces.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: New Jersey Will Expand Voting Rights, as Some States Limit Them
description: New Jersey, a state controlled by Democrats, will offer more than a week of early in-person voting for the first time before November’s election.
content: Months after a divisive presidential election pushed voting rights to the fore, the issue has become a key political battlefield.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day:
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 29, 2021.
content: “Most soldiers have never tasted democracy for their whole lives. They are still living in the dark.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: In ‘Crowns, Kinks and Curls,’ Getting to the Roots of Black Hair
description: Keli Goff’s series of vignettes feature Black women recounting how their hair affected their school lives, relationships or careers.
content: I have 4b hair that remained virgin hair, mostly styled in box braids and cornrows with extensions, until I was 13, when I got my first relaxer. My scalp has known chemical burns, hot comb burns, curling iron burns, flat iron burns and the unrelenting throbbing that comes with hours of tight root-wrenching braiding. I got my big chop at 21 and have been natural — years of T.W.A.s and twist-outs and wash ‘n’ go’s — ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Corporations, Vocal About Racial Justice, Go Quiet on Voting Rights
description: “They are complicit in their silence,” one activist said, as bills that would disproportionately affect Black citizens across the country stir public debate.
content: As Black Lives Matter protesters filled the streets last summer, many of the country’s largest corporations expressed solidarity and pledged support for racial justice. But now, with lawmakers around the country advancing restrictive voting rights bills that would have a disproportionate impact on Black voters, corporate America has gone quiet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: ‘There’s just a sense of entitlement’: Hawaiians worry about a flood of heedless tourists.
description: For much of the pandemic, Hawaii had some of the strictest rules for visitors in the United States. But now testing can replace a quarantine in most areas.
content: Palakiko Chandler took their little cousins to Nanakuli Beach on Oahu last weekend and noticed something they hadn’t seen in a while: a parking lot full of rental cars. The tourists were back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dera Menra Sijabat and Richard C. Paddock
title: Oil Refinery in Indonesia Catches Fire, Prompting an Evacuation
description: The state-owned oil company, Pertamina, which operates the refinery on the island of Java, suggested the fire may have been caused by a lightning strike.
content: JAKARTA, Indonesia — An oil refinery on the Indonesian island of Java caught fire early Monday, sending flames and smoke towering into the sky, seriously injuring six people and prompting an evacuation of nearly 1,000 nearby residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: The C.D.C. extends its moratorium on evictions until June 30 to ease hardships caused by the virus.
description: The C.D.C. issued the moratorium last fall, citing its jurisdictional authority to implement measures needed to promote public health.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has extended its nationwide moratorium on evictions through June 30, pushing it back from the end of March, when it had been scheduled to lapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kazin
title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and America’s Most Liberal Generation
description: David Freedlander’s “The AOC Generation” offers a picture of a growing electorate that may be changing American politics forever.
content: THE AOC GENERATIONHow Millennials Are Seizing Power and Rewriting the Rules of American PoliticsBy David Freedlander
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Besha Rodell
title: Attica Summer Camp, Outside Melbourne, Is a Dreamy Distraction
description: The chef Ben Shewry’s countryside pop-up is a comforting escape for pandemic times.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — This past summer in Australia had a dreamlike emotional dissonance, like pantomiming normalcy while the outside world remained overrun with illness and death. Everyone I know reads the news, speaks to loved ones in less-safe places and feels guilty that everything here is so very nice. We go to the beach, we camp and, yes, we eat in restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: The Boarding-School Boom
description: Screen-fatigued parents have been considering an education option that once seemed possible only for those in rarefied circles.
content: Boarding school had never been in the cards for Landon Moore. In December, he was a senior at Bloomington High School in Illinois; he had always assumed that his father, the school’s principal, would hand him his diploma when he graduated, as to his older brother before him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Drag Star Sasha Velour Lip-Syncs for Her Operatic Life
description: “The Island We Made,” Velour’s collaboration with the composer Angélica Negrón and the director Matthew Placek, is a meditation on motherhood.
content: Opera is about sound bellowing from someone’s throat. Lip-syncing is the opposite. While opera lovers have long been known to silently join in with recordings in the privacy of their homes, can there be a true operatic performance based on mouthing along?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Chocolate Bonbon Worthy of Gotham
description: The pastry chef Ron Paprocki has added colorful filled confections for springtime.
content: Gotham Bar & Grill has been closed for a little over a year (with plans to reopen this summer), but that hasn’t stopped the pastry chef Ron Paprocki from continuing to turn out his chocolate treats. For spring this year, there are pastel bonbons filled with passion fruit caramel, lemon olive oil and raspberry ganache. They come nestled in a gift box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Preston
title: Your Pandemic Baby’s Coming Out Party
description: Haven’t seen your family in a while? Have a grandchild you’ve never met? Visiting may be awkward at first but you can get through it.
content: No one in Deena Al Mahbuba’s family has met her daughter, Aara. She was born at the end of 2019, extremely premature. By the time Aara left the hospital for her home outside Boston in mid-June, the world was already months into Covid-19 lockdowns. Ms. Mahbuba’s close relatives, along with her husband’s, all live in Bangladesh. The couple moved from there in 2013.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: The Start-Up Enemies of Wall Street Are Booming
description: Times are flush for young tech companies like Stripe and Coinbase, which are having a moment as they upend the financial establishment.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2009, Shamir Karkal and several colleagues struggled to raise money for a banking start-up, Simple. Most of the 70 venture capital firms they met over the course of a year didn’t see the point of the idea, he said. The few that did thought it would fail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Extinction — The Facts’ and ‘Hysterical’
description: A sobering nature program with David Attenborough airs on PBS. And FX debuts a documentary about women in comedy.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, March 29-April 4. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Katie Glueck, Dana Rubinstein and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Yang and Adams Clash, Councilman Exits: 5 Takeaways From N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race
description: The campaigns of Andrew Yang and Eric Adams exchanged harsh attacks, and Carlos Menchaca, a city councilman from Brooklyn, dropped out of the race.
content: For much of the 2021 New York City mayoral campaign, the major Democratic candidates have been polite and collegial, with few flash points of tension.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Samuel Faust and Angela L. Rasmussen
title: We Can’t End the Pandemic Without Vaccinating Kids
description: So far, children have mostly been spared from the worst aspects of Covid-19. Let’s keep it that way.
content: The United States’ coronavirus vaccine rollout has finally hit its stride, with well over two million doses administered daily. Soon, vaccines will be available to all adults who want them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: The first witness is a 911 dispatcher who ‘called the police on the police’ as George Floyd was arrested.
description: The first witness to take the stand in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin on Monday was Jena Scurry, a 911 dispatcher in Minneapolis who alerted a police supervisor in May after she watched officers pin George Floyd to the ground live on a surveillance camera.
content: The first witness to take the stand in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin on Monday was Jena Scurry, a 911 dispatcher in Minneapolis who alerted a police supervisor in May after she watched officers pin George Floyd to the ground live on a surveillance camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Bloody Mary Mix, Hold the Tomatoes
description: Dirty Sue’s latest creation features all the spices you need for a strong eye-opener, but none of the tomato juice.
content: Eric “E.T.” Tecosky, the Los Angeles bartender behind the line of Dirty Sue cocktail condiments, has come up with a clever new product: a Bloody Mary mix with no tomato juice. Anyone can add tomato juice; Mr. Tecosky’s focus is the spices needed, in addition to his company’s own olive juice, to make a great drink. Each 16-ounce bottle contains enough spice solution for 21 to 32 drinks, according to taste. It’s also a terrific seasoning for gazpacho and steamed clams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Why Transgender Girls Are Suddenly the G.O.P.’s Culture-War Focus
description: Lawmakers in a growing number of Republican-led states are advancing and passing bills to bar transgender athletes in girls’ sports, a culture clash that seems to have come out of nowhere.
content: The last time Republicans in South Dakota made a serious push to bar transgender girls from school sports, in 2019, their bill was known only by its nondescript numerical title, Senate Bill 49. Its two main sponsors were men. And it died without ever getting out of committee, just 10 days after it was introduced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Cautiously, Britain Begins Relaxing Strict Lockdown Rules
description: The move to allow larger gatherings outdoors and reopen some sports centers came as many countries in Europe are tightening restrictions as their coronavirus cases shoot up.
content: LONDON — Across Germany and France, shops are closing, travel is being restricted, and the authorities are ordering people back into their homes. But in Britain, the government moved on Monday to relax its strict national lockdown, allowing people to gather outdoors in groups of up to six people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Kate Taylor
title: In San Francisco, Turmoil Over Reopening Schools Turns a City Against Itself
description: The San Francisco school board has infuriated parents and the mayor. Now it has descended into chaos over accusations of racism.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The pandemic has brought grinding frustrations for parents, educators and students across the country. But perhaps no place has matched San Francisco in its level of infighting, public outrage and halting efforts to reopen schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: A majority of school districts are now open. But not everyone wants to return.
description: The majority of the nation’s districts have begun to reopen school buildings, but some teachers have been wary of returning to in-person instruction.
content: Elementary students returned to classrooms in Long Beach, Calif., on Monday and campuses from Los Angeles to Boston prepared for significant expansions of in-person instruction as a majority of the nation’s districts have now begun to reopen school buildings, many of which have been closed for more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: Help Us Put on The Morning Newsletter’s First Event
description: The Morning newsletter will hold a live event for Times subscribers on April 15, and we want to hear from you! Please complete one or both of the following prompts, and we may feature your response as part of the event.
content: The Morning newsletter will hold a live event for Times subscribers on April 15, and we want to hear from you! Please complete one or both of the following prompts, and we may feature your response as part of the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: What we know about Eric J. Nelson, the lawyer presenting opening arguments for Derek Chauvin.
description: Mr. Nelson is one of a dozen defense lawyers in Minneapolis who represent police officers charged with misconduct and work on a rotation basis.
content: Eric J. Nelson is one of a dozen defense lawyers in Minneapolis who work on a rotation basis to represent police officers charged with misconduct. Mr. Nelson, 46, took charge of the former police officer Derek Chauvin’s defense over the summer, after his first lawyer retired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Note to Future Space Travelers: Prepare for a Shrinking Heart
description: After almost a year in space, Scott Kelly’s heart diminished, but he remained reasonably fit.
content: In space, your heart gets smaller.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Trial of Derek Chauvin
description: What we know about the prosecution, defense and jury in the trial of the former police officer accused of murdering George Floyd in Minneapolis.
content: On the docket on Monday at a Minneapolis courthouse is the biggest police brutality case in the United States in three decades: the trial of Derek Chauvin, a white former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, a Black man, last May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Biden Changes His Own ‘Paradigm’
description: The president is quietly undercutting the exact brand of center-lane politics that he worked hard to enshrine as a senator.
content: On Thursday, at his first news conference as president, Joe Biden did more than just detail his plans and take questions from reporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Cheesecake Evokes Memories
description: Sugar Hill Creamery’s new blueberry confection is available at its Harlem and Hamilton Heights shops, and nationwide.
content: Back when we had a share in a ski house at Mount Snow, Vt., we’d drive up with a cheesecake in the trunk of the car. It was frozen by the time we reached our destination and delicious to eat without thawing. The new blueberry ice cream cheesecake that Nicholas Larsen and Petrushka Bazin Larsen have introduced at their Sugar Hill Creamery in Harlem evoked that taste memory. Theirs is not a cheesecake, strictly speaking: It is made from ice cream that has a cream-cheese base, set on a spiced graham cracker crust with a topping of blueberry gelée. Remove it from the freezer about 10 minutes before serving. Fresh blueberries lightly stewed in a little maple syrup are excellent alongside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Pryor
title: F.D.R. Took Down Giants. Biden Can, Too.
description: Roosevelt’s choice to run the antitrust wing of the Justice Department, Robert Jackson, took just 14 months to change the country.
content: During his nomination hearing, Attorney General Merrick Garland said he would “vigorously” enforce U.S. antitrust law. As the Biden administration actively considers who will lead that enforcement effort as the head of the Department of Justice’s antitrust division, they should look to the legacy of Franklin Delano Roosevelt for inspiration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: What to know about Jerry W. Blackwell, the prosecutor making opening arguments.
description: Mr. Blackwell has represented a series of large companies and joined the attorney general’s office just for this case on a pro bono basis.
content: The lawyer making opening arguments for the prosecution is Jerry W. Blackwell, a lawyer who has represented a series of large companies and joined the attorney general’s office just for this case on a pro bono basis, meaning he will not be paid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Could the Pandemic Spell the End of U.K.’s High Speed Rail?
description: Critics say HS2, a $140 billion project sold as a green alternative to planes and cars, makes less sense than ever in a world where people work from home.
content: STEEPLE CLAYDON, England — A chorus of bird song gives way to the roar of a chain saw and then the creaking and splintering of timber. A 50-foot tree sways, wobbles and finally crashes to the ground, while protesters shout and jeer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Ballpark Half Full and Another Half Empty for All 30 Teams
description: Reasons for optimism and pessimism abound. Catch up with where each team stands ahead of opening day.
content: In baseball these days, it’s all about perception and percentage. As the country stirs cautiously back to normal life, each ballpark comes with its own set of pandemic restrictions: 12 percent capacity at Fenway Park in Boston, 25 percent capacity at Marlins Park in Miami — even (gulp) 100 percent capacity for the opener at Globe Life Field in Arlington, Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: M. Wells Offers Its Cassoulet Bowls
description: The blue and white dishes are made by Janet Belden, a potter in Long Island City, Queens.
content: Cassoulet season has ended, but the handmade bowls that M. Wells in Long Island City, Queens, commissioned to bake and serve theirs this year are timeless. The blue-and-white pottery pieces, in slightly varied designs and tones, can just as easily hold servings of bouillabaisse or be used for summer berries, cherries, a thatch of coleslaw or crudités. They’re made by Janet Belden, a local potter, with a Majolica-style glaze, and they are oven and microwave-safe. Each is about eight inches in diameter with a capacity just shy of a quart. You might start to think about Mother’s Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Action Bronson, Eater by Trade, Finds a New Craving: Fitness
description: The rapper, chef and TV host has shed 130 pounds during the pandemic, dieting and exercising with the same intensity he once brought to the table.
content: One Saturday morning last month, Action Bronson was on the water at 7, staring down one burly wave after the next. Paddling around on a bodyboard, he was at Skudin Surf at American Dream, a 1.5 million-gallon wave pool in the middle of a three-million-square-foot mall and entertainment complex — a little touch of Dubai in East Rutherford, N.J.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Why Big Tech Should Fear Amy Klobuchar
description: The Minnesota senator presents her case for why regulating companies like Facebook and Google is crucial for the future of our democracy.
content: Senator Amy Klobuchar is trying to hold big tech to account and in the process “make antitrust cool again.” She believes that, because of their size and power, companies like Facebook, Google and Twitter have become a dangerous threat to American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden will share the details of his infrastructure plan and a first look at his budget plans.
description: President Biden and his administration will lay out a sweeping array of proposals for increased federal spending this week, including the first look at his budget plans for the year and the details of his much-anticipated infrastructure plan.
content: President Biden and his administration will lay out a sweeping array of proposals for increased federal spending this week, including the first look at his budget plans for the year and the details of his much-anticipated infrastructure plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Shaila Dewan
title: The case against Derek Chauvin will center on proving George Floyd’s cause of death.
description: With the central question of the case being exactly how Mr. Floyd died, and what role Mr. Chauvin’s actions played, the state indicated it would cast a much wider net than just relying on the autopsy report of the county medical examiner by bringing in a number of medical experts.
content: With the central question of the case being exactly how Mr. Floyd died, and what role Mr. Chauvin’s actions played, the state indicated it would cast a much wider net than just relying on the autopsy report of the county medical examiner by bringing in a number of medical experts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Can’t Republicans Be Populists?
description: The establishment has been routed, but its economic orthodoxy rules.
content: President Biden’s American Rescue Plan is incredibly popular, even among Republican voters. We don’t have details yet on the next big Democratic initiative, but we can expect it to poll well, because we know that it will combine major infrastructure spending with tax hikes on corporations and the rich — which are all popular things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Takeaways from the first day of the Derek Chauvin trial.
description: The prosecution’s opening remarks focused on nine minutes and 29 seconds of bystander video.
content: One of the most closely watched court cases in decades got underway on Monday as the murder trial began for Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer who is being charged with murder in the death of George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times
